RE: Brittany Michelle Gilliland v. Christopher Blaine McGregor
Case No: 70-DR-23-900051.01
Our File No.: 300.036
Dear Tom:
I wanted to follow up on your August 6, 2024, letter regarding the proposed order.
Reunification Specialist and Counseling Costs— My client has reached out to a reunification
therapist named Kelly Turner, who has agreed to work with the family. The cost for the sessions
is $150.00 per session. Considering that getting these two to agree is about as likely as winning
the lottery, and considering that the father will not be participating in these sessions, there is no
need for mutual agreement on the specific counselor. To ensure the costs remain fair and
manageable, we propose placing a cap of $150 per session, with each parent responsible for $75.
This arrangement makes sure that we are adhering to the divorce order’s 50/50 cost-sharing
provision for uncovered medical expenses, while protecting the parties financially. It may be
beneficial to set up a phone conference with Ms. Turner and us, to address any concerns we might
have after further discussion with clients.
Joint Counseling Sessions—Regarding joint sessions between A.K. and Ms. Gilliland, the Child
Advocacy Center has informed us that they will not be able to provide joint counseling sessions at
this time. It is our understanding that the CAC counselor is willing to conduct joint sessions at
some point in the future, and once they are open to that, Mother will absolutely participate. We
have no intention of infringing on the current counselor’s plans.
Taking this into account, and as we discussed on our phone call, we do not believe there is
a need to bring in a third counselor. We suggest that until the CAC’s counseling plans allow for
Mother to engage in joint sessions with A.K., the weekly reunification counseling sessions with
the reunification specialist will be sufficient and the most cost-effective approach for both parties.
We are exploring alternative options and will inform you once we have a recommendation.
However, I want to reiterate that our clients do not need to mutually agree on a counselor for these
sessions, as this would only introduce unnecessary conflict. If all goes well, once the CAC’s
counseling plan is concluded, it would probably be beneficial for A.K. and Mother to continue
counselling with Ms. Turner, provided no ethical conflicts exist, once she submits her reunification

report to the court. If Ms. Turner does have some sort of conflict at the “conclusion” of the
reunification sessions, they could continue joint counseling with another counselor.
Wednesday Dinners—Regarding the weekly dinners, the judge was particularly clear about the
importance of having a set day for these dinners to occur, and he emphasized that these dinners
should take precedence over other plans. Wednesday was chosen because A.K. does not have any
cheerleading, church activities, or other extracurriculars scheduled for that day. Both parents may
need to adjust their schedules accordingly, as this is going to be Mother’s only time outside of
counseling to spend with her daughter.
These weekly dinners are important. They are crucial for reuniting mother and daughter.
Both parties represented at the hearing that they want what is best for A.K. and to support the
reunification process. Having a set weekly dinner every Wednesday is going to be the core of that
effort. If the parties can agree on an alternative day, we are open to that discussion, and will include
that in the proposed order. However, if they cannot agree on another day prior to filing the
proposed order, the default should remain Wednesday, and this dinner should take priority over
other activities.
It is clear that we are not going to get a signed order with dinner details by tomorrow, so
until we do get an order (considering we might agree on a different day), Judge Perryman did state
on the record that the dinners should occur Wednesday evenings. Accordingly, my client intends
to attend weekly dinners with A.K., Father, and son, on Wednesday evenings, until otherwise
ordered.
Should you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact me at 334.759.7557, or
by email at matt@agricolalaw.com. Thank you.
Very truly yours,
Matthew Holdren
Cc: Barbara H. Agricola
